Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: MobiBench: Benchmarking Mobility Models for Simulation and Design of Future Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: With the explosion of new mobile apps, protocols and services, there is a compelling need for new tools to evaluate and test mobile networks. This project aims to establish a systematic framework to produce benchmarks (called MobiBench) in the form of evaluation scenarios and test-suites for mobile networking protocols and services for user and vehicular mobility. Two threads of research are pursued. First, a multi-dimensional metric space is introduced for characterization of user (human) mobility, to be applied to mobility measurements and models. The metrics span: i. individual, ii. pair-wise and iii. collective mobility dimensions, and facilitate comprehensive analysis and evaluation of mobility models and networking protocols. Novel, trace-driven models are developed to accurately capture user mobility metrics and mobile network performance. The COBRA model is designed to capture collective communal behavior in mobile social networks. Second, new extensive vehicular traces are collected and analyzed, including vehicular imagery data from thousands of webcams around the world. Vehicular density distributions and models are developed to aid in establishing realistic vehicular mobility models and benchmarks. Estimation of vehicular density uses adapted background subtraction algorithms for image processing. This work will result in the establishment of a library of benchmarks, traces, models and test-suites for pedestrian and vehicular mobility, to be used for the realistic evaluation of future mobile protocols, networks and services. Results of this research will impact mobile networking research and aid in traffic control and transportation congestion mitigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal for the project was to introduce a systematic framework for testing and evaluation of mobile (pedestrian and vehicular) networks, and Internet of Things (IoT). This was achieved through several investigative activities:
1- Mobility and network traffic modeling for pedestrians: Using a multi-dimensional analysis approach, across device types, space, time, mobility and traffic features, several main outcomes were obtained.
i- Several orders of magnitude difference were found in mobility and traffic features between the users of smartphones versus laptops. The vast majority of existing data-driven studies and models, have been established based on traces from laptops only. Our findings point to the need to re-visit this modeling work in light of the results of our studies. The investigation also found great value in integrated mobility and traffic models and features, and value in spatio-temporal multi-dimensional analyses. Incorporating such features was found to increase the ability to classify device types (from 65% to 91%) by using combined features of mobility, traffic and predictability.

ii- The project also analyzed encounter duration distribution for indoor mobility, which tended to follow power-law distribution in over 60% of the cases. Furthermore, device encounters showed a very strong correlation with traffic profiles for the encountered users, regardless of device types. The correlation was most pronounced when the encounter duration is relatively long (above 5mins). Using such correlations and data, a deep neural network was built to infer node encounters based on their traffic with over 90% accuracy.

iii- Using several prediction algorithms, including Markov Chains to neural networks, smartphones were found to be much less predicable than laptops (by 25%). Complex neural networks achieved only very modest improvement over the much simpler Markov Chain predictor. In all cases, prediction of pedestrians depends on spatio-temporal granularity and are often much worse than suggested by well-publicized entropy-based theoretical studies in the area.


2- Large-scale vehicular simulations: Using extensive imagery data of vehicular traffic, and the introduction and development of a vehicular mobility simulator (called En-route), facilitated the analysis and design of vehicular-related system, such as connected cars, participatory sensing of road and city conditions, and shared transportation.
The simulator integrates city-scale imagery data with annotated road maps, to generate trips and study traffic characteristics. The resulting speed and density distributions of the simulator matched the real data closely.

Trip duration and distance distribution in a city was found to follow Gamma and log-normal distributions. The mobility data was integrated with the commonly used SUMO simulator for transportation studies.


3- Shared transportation and trip matching studies: Several types of shared transportation models were studied, including ride sharing, car sharing, and catch-a-ride. With the introduction of trip similarities in time-and-space, meaningful clusters of trips were identified using low-complexity (linear-in-time) algorithms. 
This is promising for matching similar trips for the purposes of shared transportation, crowd sourcing (and crowd sensing), and/or vehicular connectivity. The objectives include minimizing total distance driven, or number of cars needed.


4- Vehicular traffic forecast: Traffic intensity data collected from 58 cameras in a city was used to investigate congestion forecast algorithms. Comparing various techniques, it was found that neural networks clearly outperform seasonal models. 
Dramatic reduction in forecast error was obtained using the proposed deep learning (62% less error vs seasonal models). A novel algorithm was introduced that predicts all cameras/location in one shot (in half the time) with less than 15% prediction error. One main strength of the proposed scheme is the use of spatial interpolation in understanding the patterns of traffic across the city with limited vantage points. 
Furthermore, the scheme was able to reconstruct the future of the target city location using imagery data from other locations (even from one location in the city to predict 57 other locations) with relatively high accuracy. These algorithms can potentially help alleviate traffic congestions in major cities, and improve vehicular mobility.


5- Encounter distance estimation for tracking disease spread: One vision of future intelligent hospitals is its ability to track disease spread and infection. A main factor in determining infection is people encounters, their duration and distance. This project studied the use of bluetooth technologies for the accurate estimation of encounter distances. 
The use of various transmission power levels in bluetooth low energy (BLE), along with new data-driven machine learning algorithms, resulted in greatly improved accuracy for distance estimation and classification. The algorithms can provide accurate estimates of encounters that are, for example, less than 1m, between 1m and 3m, and greater than 3m. 
The proposed algorithms hold great promise in identifying populations at risk for disease spread, using bluetooth encounters and measurements in intelligent hospitals settings.

Overall, great effort was exerted to share the anonymous data, and the developed code and tools. This enables the reproducibility of the results, and the publications findings. This was achieved through the MobiLib library and website.


Last Modified: 03/02/2020
Modified by: Ahmed Helmy

This was achieved through several investigative activities: 1- Mobility and network traffic modeling for pedestrians: Using a multi-dimensional analysis approach, across device types, space, time, mobility and traffic features, several main outcomes were obtained. i- Several orders of magnitude difference were found in mobility and traffic features between the users of smartphones versus laptops. The vast majority of existing data-driven studies and models, have been established based on traces from laptops only. Our findings point to the need to re-visit this modeling work in light of the results of our studies. The investigation also found great value in integrated mobility and traffic models and features, and value in spatio-temporal multi-dimensional analyses. Incorporating such features was found to increase the ability to classify device types (from 65% to 91%) by using combined features of mobility, traffic and predictability. ii- The project also analyzed encounter duration distribution for indoor mobility, which tended to follow power-law distribution in over 60% of the cases. Furthermore, device encounters showed a very strong correlation with traffic profiles for the encountered users, regardless of device types. Using such correlations and data, a deep neural network was built to infer node encounters based on their traffic with over 90% accuracy. iii- Using several prediction algorithms, including Markov Chains to neural networks, smartphones were found to be much less predicable than laptops (by 25%). Complex neural networks achieved only very modest improvement over the much simpler Markov Chain predictor. In all cases, prediction of pedestrians depends on spatio-temporal granularity and are often much worse than suggested by well-publicized entropy-based theoretical studies in the area. 2- Large-scale vehicular simulations: Using extensive imagery data of vehicular traffic, and the introduction and development of a vehicular mobility simulator (called En-route), facilitated the analysis and design of vehicular-related system, such as connected cars, participatory sensing of road and city conditions, and shared transportation. The mobility data was integrated with the commonly used SUMO simulator for transportation studies. 3- Shared transportation and trip matching studies: Several types of shared transportation models were studied, including ride sharing, car sharing, and catch-a-ride. With the introduction of trip similarities in time-and-space, meaningful clusters of trips were identified using low-complexity (linear-in-time) algorithms. These algorithms can potentially help alleviate traffic congestions in major cities, and improve vehicular mobility. 5- Encounter distance estimation for tracking disease spread: One vision of future intelligent hospitals is its ability to track disease spread and infection. A main factor in determining infection is people encounters, their duration and distance. This project studied the use of bluetooth technologies for the accurate estimation of encounter distances. The use of various transmission power levels in bluetooth low energy (BLE), along with new data-driven machine learning algorithms, resulted in greatly improved accuracy for distance estimation and classification. The algorithms can provide accurate estimates of encounters that are, for example, less than 1m, between 1m and 3m, and greater than 3m. The proposed algorithms hold great promise in identifying populations at risk for disease spread, using bluetooth encounters and measurements in intelligent hospitals settings. Overall, great effort was exerted to share the anonymous data, and the developed code and tools. This enables the reproducibility of the results, and the publications findings. This was achieved through the MobiLib library and website. Last Modified: 03/02/2020 Submitted by: Ahmed Helmy
